segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 My name is Kuba Grecki. It's a huge honor to be the first speaker this year. Thank you,
Dorota and Andrzej for picking me to be actually the first person today. And today I will be
talking about how a smooth sea never made a skilled fisherman. I'll be talking about the
toolkits that the red teams use and how it should be much better than the bad guys are using.
Because the bad guys' toolkits are evolving and it should be the same in general for the red teams.
So quickly about me. My name is Kuba Grecki. I'm an offensive security tools developer,
also ex-MMO game hacker. I used to write bots for online games like 20 years ago where I learned
all the skills that I'm using today. I also run a blog that's at breakdev.org. I write about my
own research and also about the tools that I'm releasing and updating. I am the creator of Evil
Jinx, so you can also refer to me as that Evil Jinx guy like some people do, because that's what
I'm mostly just known for. And I'm also releasing Evil Jinx Pro this year. So this is also what the
talk will be mainly about. I've released Poundrop. It's like a Dropbox for red teams tool
that I released several years ago. It is unfortunately a bit outdated right now,
but I plan to do something about it and maybe integrate it with Evil Jinx at one point.
Last year, I also started this community that's called BreakDev Red. It's a community for red
teamers, and I only allow people to join who actually exist, so no anonymous access. The
entrance is free, but basically every person that wants to join needs to be pre-approved
to maintain the quality of content and discussions inside and to make sure that
everyone is actually on the red teams inside. I have also released a course on how to use Evil
Jinx. I made the tool hard enough to use that I had to release the course to teach people how to
do it. And here I have to say a huge thank you to every one of you who actually bought the course.
I know that there are some people in the audience here, because this actually makes it possible for
me to work on Evil Jinx Pro this year and also the last year, and this is actually why it's
possible to self-fund this whole project. As mentioned, it all started actually at ZipCon.
Seven years ago, I had a lightning talk during the lunchtime break. It was like 15 minutes. It was my
first time at ZipCon, also my first cyber security conference, I believe, and also my first time
speaking. I had this Wi-Fi hacking hardware that was based on Raspberry Pi with connected
cables to it, and I was presenting it. And at the end, when I actually showed the credits and
other things I did, I mentioned briefly Evil Jinx that I released just like a month before.
And after I actually ended the presentation, someone from the audience actually approached me
and told me, man, why didn't you actually talk about this project instead? So then I thought,
maybe there is something there. So then apparently a lot of people actually liked the project and
have been using it ever since, and then later I released Evil Jinx second version and the third
version. But what the talk is about is like defenses against phishing are evolving. Phishing
is getting harder. Black market phishing toolkits keep evolving, and the red teamers are essentially
left alone with open source toolkits that they have to somehow like glue up together and make it
work, and there's a lot of effort that every red teamer has to put into making all the open source
toolkits actually work that you probably know yourself. And I actually plan to help and solve
this problem for everyone, and this is with the release of Evil Jinx Pro that supposedly
will come sometime later this year, and I want to solve all the issues that actually red teams have
regarding the setup, the infrastructure, the maintenance as well for it, and also the
detection part. And the detection part regarding phishing, like Evil Jinx is a reverse phishing
framework, and the main issue with it is your links get detected, like there is like this red
red panel shown in Chrome when your phishing link is detected, and how to prevent
scanners from accessing it. And as well, first of all, I wanted to like address the elephant
in the room, like because I'm writing offensive security tools, so they are open source, and
I am also giving like the bad guys the capability to do the bad things. So what can we do? The bad
guys like phishing, the bad guys like free tools. Red teams need to simulate the bad guys, and the
red teams also need the better tools than the bad guys are actually using, but we cannot give the
bad guys the tools that the red teams have which would be better than they are using. So it's
basically will turn into a loop. So I was thinking how can I actually prevent that so that I can
create a tool that actually makes the red teamer lives easier, but not give it out to the bad guys.
And that's why I created this break the red community, like I mentioned before, that's like
a vetted community for people who work specifically on red teams, and I know that they exist, and they
work for another company that is also red teaming. So it actually gives like this good environment
for people to share your TTPs and not be worried too much about them being used by bad actors,
and also Evil Jinx Pro will be only available once it releases to the people who actually join
the community. So here I want to jump in into what will be available in Evil Jinx Pro once it
releases. On the second part of the talk, I want to also focus on one of the technical
sites. So first one will be more like a bit of an advertisement about the features, and later I will
actually teach you something interesting. So first of all, I redid Evil Jinx to have a client
server architecture. So like you remember, Evil Jinx right now you have to SSH into a server,
configure it, and it's like a client and a server in one thing. So right now it's separated.
We have a client that connects to several different servers on the outside,
and you can also deploy servers from the client. So there's like just one command that you just
set up the IP, your SSH key or the root password, set up the username, and you type in deploy,
it will automatically deploy to the server that you want. No need to SSH anymore to every server,
just to make sure that everything is working, and also I have added a multi-user collaboration. So
now if you have several people actually working on a specific set of on one campaign that for
example encapsulates several servers, they can all connect to one server, and one person can
create lures like set up the campaign, set up the fishlets, the other one can actually start
preparing different things, and you can all see the actions in real time together what you are
doing. It's like similar like a team server on any kind of C2 framework. So I have also been
thinking about how to hide the API. There's also like a public API that's being exposed, and you
have to use a special SNI host name to connect to Evil Jinx on port 443, so like the whole API is
pretty well hidden, because if someone doesn't know the randomly generated host name, they will
not be able to access this API. This is probably like a technical detail that I'll explain sometime
later. This is a set of commands that should deploy one server that you want. So you basically
just add a server with the IP and its name, then you register it with the server, which is the
licensing server, and then you type in deploy, and that should be it. Now also Evil Jinx, because
it's a client server, it has a client server architecture, it has the full API that's accessible
through HTTP requests or persistent web socket connections, and here's like a sample of the
response that you get from the Evil Jinx server to grab the list of sessions. So I'm really eager
to see if the community in the future will try to use it to automate some of the stuff that
Evil Jinx is doing, and maybe like use some kind of this AI hype to do phishing automation or
whatever. There's also Evil Puppet, which is the module that I also talked about last year. This is
like a background browser that's controllable with phishlets, and essentially what
it allows you, it allows you to extract specific shadow tokens from the legitimate session that's
running in the background. I covered it a bit in the other talks, but here you can see that it will
trigger on when the phished user is actually approaching this path that is being outlined
here, it will open the login page in the background browser, grab the username that the user entered
in real-time on the phishing session in their own browser, then type it in and also type in
the password and later click the button to submit, and once the post request actually is initiated,
it will grab this shadow token that is crucial to inject into the reverse proxy session to not
get the account blocked, because it contains browser telemetry that has to be retrieved from
the legitimate browser. That should probably be a separate talk, so I'll just talk about it a bit
briefly here. There's also a reverse proxy as a website spoofer, so for now all of the unauthorised
requests to Evil Jinx actually resulted in the redirection to the rickroll video or the
other website that you specified, but this time you can actually proxy another website the same way
as in general Evil Jinx works, it will reverse proxy the content from another website and show
it in context of the phishing domain that you are using. So this is a bit more convenient because
it allows you to present that your phishing domain is actually hosting a legitimate website and you
don't have to put like some kind of static content that can be easily fingerprintable, you can
specify whichever URL you want. So here as an example I use the Cameron's World website that
is being proxied through linkedin.fake.com. Another thing, TLS wildcard certificates, so you know that
Evil Jinx currently is able to retrieve and renew certificates from Let's Encrypt, but all the TLS
certificates are registered for the full hostname with the subdomain, and this is actually an issue
because every time you ever register a TLS certificate, maybe some of you don't know because
I didn't know before, this certificate gets published in the TLS transparency log which is
publicly accessible worldwide. So all of the bots and scanners that try to look for phishing URLs
and scan the phishing links will retrieve the domains from there and start looking if this is
a website that's hosting a fake login page or whatever, and that's when the scanning begins.
So with the wildcard certificates this problem just vanishes because the wildcard certificate
will hide the subdomain that you are using in your hostname, so the bots would have to brute
force the subdomain to find your hostname. So this actually prevents the majority of
scannings from the bots worldwide. There is also automated JavaScript obfuscation implemented. I
use the engine that's hosted on obfuscator.io, and every injected script into the landing page
that you're using in your phishlets, or it's JavaScript that's injected to handle the redirection
to the real website afterwards, after the phishing is a success, every script is actually
dynamically obfuscated. It's cached for five minutes and then it re-obfuscates it, but it
actually prevents any kind of scanners to fingerprint the scripts that you want to
inject into your phishing landing pages and protect them from signature matching.
Then I have also rewritten the database to SQLite. Before it was BundDB, it was a long
time ago before actually there was no SQL driver for Go to be written natively. You had to use C
and compile it through the C libraries and it would then rely on the libc version, so it was
hard to make one binary that would work on all distributions, so, sorry, Melvin, I don't know
if Melvin made it today, but you will have to probably rewrite the bobber. This is like a very
nice thing that Melvin from TrustedSec actually released and made like this triforce of free
tools working together, and it was reliant on actually retrieving the data from the BundDB
database. Another thing, it's the external DNS management. For now, Evil Jinx had a local name
server working on the same host as the phishing server, so you had to point the domain, the
phishing domain that you registered, you had to point the name servers to the IP of the Evil Jinx
server, which was kind of suspicious and probably if someone looked into it, it would be pretty
much easy to tell that it is like a phishing instance that's just hosting the name server on
the same IP as the phishing server, and now you can actually avoid that, and Evil Jinx supports
the use of external DNS providers like CloudFlare, DigitalOcean and Route53 for now, AWS and more
will come, so basically all of this is doable through the libDNS library that actually provides
like this interface for any API that I can put into it, so let me know later if there is any
DNS provider that you want implemented that you are using on a daily basis, and this will give me
a great feedback. And now we go into JA4 signature spoofing, so first of all I wanted to ask how
many of you know what is JA4 or JA3? Okay, great, that may be interesting, so this is something
that came up like a pretty new thing, so basically it is used to fingerprint the software that is
initiating the TLS handshake and establishing the TLS connection, so what I did, I implemented the
spoofing of this, but let's dive now deeper to the more technical part of this talk and talk more
about JA4. So JA4 plus is essentially like a suite of network fingerprinting algorithms, you could
say, like it generates signatures for several different types of handshakes that you can use,
but we will be focusing in this talk only on the TLS handshake, and more specifically,
of course I have to credit, it was made by John Althaus, the JA4 from Fox IO, a really great guy,
I talked to him briefly about a few things, and it is a successor to JA3, JA3 I think was
released by a different company before and now John is releasing JA4 under his own company,
if I'm not mistaken. So in general, the JA4 is a signature generated from the TLS handshake
client hello packet, so if you know, like this is the client hello packet,
gives the server the information, what is the TLS version it supports, what is the ALPN, so if the
client that's initiating the TLS connection supports HTTP 1.1 or does it also support HTTP
2 or even QUIC, that is also embedded in this client hello packet. It lists all the supported
cipher suites with which the secure communication will be established, and it also lists the list
of TLS extensions that are used, and one of the TLS extensions that you probably are familiar
with is the SNI extension, which actually outputs the host name of the server that you are
connecting to, so basically it gives the firewalls the ability to tell what domain the client is
trying to connect to before the connection is actually encrypted, so this is sent in plain text
so it can be intercepted and scanned. This is how the JA4 fingerprint signature looks like,
it's basically divided into three sections, there is an A section, B section and a C section,
no pun intended, and the first section actually tells you what is the TCP, what is the protocol,
TLS version, if it supports SNI on the host name or the IP, number of cipher suites and the other
things. The second part, the B part is what we will be mostly focusing on, and this actually
tells what is the list of, it sorts the list of all the codes for all the cipher suites and
creates a signature, it hashes the full set of the list of these codes, and the third section
that we will not be focusing on is just the hash of all the extensions that are being sent in the
client hello packet. So this is a screenshot from Wireshark, and in Wireshark you can see that the
client hello packet, so this is basically the reading of what the client hello packet looks
like in Wireshark, you can take a look yourself when you have free time and this is where the
cipher suites are listed and this is the list of extensions. This is when I expanded the drop down,
you can see the codes for each cipher suite which are being used to generate this signature,
so the J4 in raw form, you can see the first section before the underscore is the same,
because it just has information about the other characteristics of the connection,
but the second B part is just a list of all of the codes for the cipher suites, and later it is,
there is I think the SHA256 hash I think taken out of it and truncated into 12 characters.
So here let's take a look what are the most common applications, what are the J4 signatures,
and here you can take a look at Google Chrome for example which is take only look at the middle
section, at the B section, because the other ones will vary, will be different too often,
and what I want you to take a closer look at is the sliver malware and evil jinx,
like you can tell that the middle section is the same, and the funny thing is they are both
written in Go language, so they use the same Go TLS library which has the same list of supported
cipher suites and if you do not change it you can basically fingerprint every software that's
connecting to you that was written in Go language, so this is like a clear way to block evil jinx
from talking to the destination server that attackers are trying to attack.
So scouting for prey, the Google Chrome J4B signature is this one, you can remember it
because it will be mentioned later in the talk, there is also this Golang signature that I
mentioned, and you can think like who actually uses J3 or J4, is there any service, and basically
Cloudflare of course is using it, I had an issue with evil jinx previously, I think like a year
ago when I did some tests, and whenever a page was actually protected with Cloudflare, immediately
when I went into the phishing page that was proxied by evil jinx I got presented with the
captcha that I had to solve, and I had no idea why or how exactly it is happening because it
made no sense, and later when I actually customised and modified several of the cipher
suites that the Go is using and I just added I think two, removed a few, then this captcha
stopped appearing, so it actually proven to me that Cloudflare is doing this kind of thing,
scanning for J3 or J4 signatures. So what can be done in terms of the attackers, how can we
prevent the hunters from basically, well not the hunters, but how can we prevent the destination
server from knowing that they are using evil jinx. So this is basically what I mentioned,
you can modify the list of supported TLS ciphers if you need, and also there is this UTLS library
that I implemented into evil jinx pro that basically will randomise the list of cipher
suites every time the connection is made to prevent any kind of, any form of blacklisting
of the J4 signature. So it gives you different J4 signatures with every TLS connection,
and it's also good to avoid J4 blacklists. So this is enough until defenders deploy more advanced
detections, and probably they will, I even have a few ideas, maybe not a good idea to share them
right now, but there is also another option when a client connects to the phishing server which
hosts evil jinx, you can actually grab the TLS client hello packet that's coming from the client's
browser, and you can copy the list of the cipher suites into the connection that evil jinx is
making to the destination server, so that it actually mimics the client, the real client to
the server. So what, then I get, I had the idea, if the servers can actually detect evil jinx,
what about actually detecting who is connecting to evil jinx itself, like all the bots that are
actually scanning the phishing links and things like, is it possible to actually harness the power
of J4 to actually make it in reverse and make the hunters become the hunted? So then you basically
have evil jinx becoming the defender, and the tables have turned. So basically I decided that
it would be maybe a good idea to reinvent the wheel, because why not? Like it's always a great
idea. So Cloudflare is already great at detecting the bots. This is like their entire business model.
So basically let's try to see what Cloudflare is great at, and do the same thing.
There is a Cloudflare turnstile that you can use with evil jinx. This is like mainly
their service to detect bots in real time to prevent you also from showing the capture.
It only shows the capture whenever it detects some anomalies. You can check it out. I made
like a proof of concept that you can actually use turnstile with evil jinx as a redirector, so it
will protect your phishing pages with turnstile. But why not implement our own bot guard that would
be available in evil jinx pro like by default? And behold, it's a poor man's Cloudflare idea. So it's
like a very cheap version probably, but I decided to do it properly and prepare with some kind of
research. So I forked the Go vhost library that I've been using to extract the host names from
the SNI extension data, and I added the code to generate J4 signatures for every connection that's
actually coming into evil jinx, because the code for Go was not publicly available, so I used
the documentation that John outhouse published and wrote my own signature calculation
code. And then I set up the logging so that every time I got the connection to evil jinx, I would
log the IP J4, some additional telemetry that I will talk about a bit later. And then I will have
some data set to analyze later. Later, I also disabled the usage of wildcard certificates,
because like I told you, if you don't use wildcard certificates, the bots will immediately
start scanning your server. And that was my that's what I wanted to do for a change. So basically,
I wanted every bot to scan my website while I was gathering as much data as possible. I also
uploaded the phishing link to every URL scanning service I could find like virus total, others
that I found randomly on the on the internet. And then I waited. So I gathered the data for a bit
like one month. And what were the results, I got like a total of 820 requests to my phishing links,
and also to phishing domains, and they came from 680 unique IP. So you can see like, what is the
percentage of unique IP is being used. And this actually also proven to me that IP blacklisting
is that these days, it's like, I even saw one bot scanning my, my page in real time, it was
scanning this spoof page that I was actually retrieving from the external resource. And it
was scanning every single URL it found in the HTML content. And the origin IP was different with
every request. So they are definitely using IP rotating services. So IP blacklisting basically
makes no sense these days. I've also logged the ASNs for every IP that I got just in case I could
see some kind of maybe patterns of what organisations use what IP ranges and maybe just
scan I don't know, I saw Palo Alto, ASN or others, but essentially, there were too many to make any
kind of reliable information out of it. And here like a plug for IP info, like thanks to these
guys, because they release free databases of ASNs and also IP to get a location which they
update daily and you can just download it so and use it in your own projects, which is pretty
amazing. So the most popular J4B signatures that I encountered during this test, and this is
actually pretty, it was actually pretty sad to see because 80% of all requests came from Google
Chrome, which they had like the J4B signature, there were only like 11% of requests originating
from Go software and the Google bot because it advertised itself in the user agent was just
1% and it also has the unique J4 signature. So the result, it was a partial failure.
The J4 signatures on their own are not enough to detect bots, unfortunately, because most bots use
the Chrome engine, like the headless browsers and things like that. But then I had a new idea,
like all the phish users that you are actually attacking as a red team must have JavaScript
enabled because otherwise the login page will not work, like JavaScript is everywhere these days.
So it is safe to assume that JavaScript will always be available on the target system. How
many bots actually are able to run JavaScript? And that's what I wanted to find out. So before
I also started this, I started gathering telemetry through the injected JavaScript
that I had in every landing page of my phishing server, and it would report back the telemetry
to the Evil Jinx server for analysis in real time, like through the AJAX request,
then Evil Jinx actually analyses it and then spits back information as a response, whether
it's allowed or not for this user to connect. And the question was, like, how many page views
out of this whole 820 resulted in telemetry data being sent back to the Evil Jinx server,
which meant how many of these bots actually did run JavaScript? And the answer was 35.
So that was pretty amazing, like, how these bots work and how little of them actually have
JavaScript enabled. So then I began analysing browser telemetry that actually got returned
to Evil Jinx. So I decided to go for the low-hanging fruit because that probably would
result in the less false positives, and there were, like, really tons of... I also mentioned,
I think, there's the FP collect library that I used to collect this information in JavaScript.
Then I decided to analyse the telemetry, and I would get the browser window size and the user
agent. For analysing the user agent, I used the UA parser library that you can see a link to here.
It would only help me to grab the name of the browser, OS, and the version.
So first I started with window size analysis. So that may seem a bit like a joke, but it was
actually interesting to see that most of the... so basically browser window is divided into two
specific sets. It's the inner window and the outer window. The inner window is what you see
except for the toolbar and the edges, I believe, and the outer window is what you have
as a full window of what you are running. And most of the bots actually
seems to be using a very generic screen dimensions, and they seem they all are running
in full screen mode. I tested on my own PC, and you can only get these kind of results if you
actually type in F11 in Chrome to put the page into full screen. So it was pretty unlikely
that you would be phishing a target who uses exclusively a browser in full screen mode. I
don't know if you maybe encountered any cases like that, but to me, it seems pretty unlikely.
So this is like the first thing that I started to detect. Then there was also another case that
the outer window was actually smaller than the inner window. How is it possible? How can you
make the window smaller and the inner window bigger? That made no sense. So I started Googling
it a bit, and apparently you can do it when you zoom out the page with control and minus,
but then also the device pixel ratio gets below one, and every bot actually reported
that the device pixel ratio to be always one, and it never changed. So this was another
signature that something was suspicious about the browser that's connecting to your website.
Another thing was a natural unrealistic window sizes. Outer window of size one pixel is pretty
much not possible. And then I began to do the browser version analysis, and I could see that
almost all, like I'm talking about 95 per cent probably of all browsers that ever contacted
Evil Jinx had outdated browser versions. So, defenders, if you're writing the bots, just
make sure to at least keep the user agent updated with all the updates, because it's really the
lowest hanging fruit, because it is very unlikely for any request to come from the browser that is
six months older or anything. Then there was this interesting case that I found, and I couldn't tell
what, how to, I knew that it is a bot, because it used the link that I specifically prepared for the
bots, and it actually reported an iPhone running the Safari browser connecting to my server,
and the window dimensions looked pretty okay. I don't know what are the dimensions of the iPhone
maybe you can figure out if something is fishy about it. Then the version was pretty up-to-date,
and I was thinking what else can I look into? So I looked at the other telemetry that was also
gathered, and I saw like the video card data. The video card was made by Google, and it was
angled, and I later Googled this angle thing, and I think I saw, if I remember correctly, it was only
for Android devices, essentially, and then I also compared it with the JA4 signature that I also
captured, and it told me that it was actually Chromium engine connecting, so it was not really
Safari on the iPhone. I could tell by cross-checking all this data that I gathered that it was actually
a fake user agent. So it was not Safari really. So the real detection power comes from cross-checking
all this data through the all different sensors. So JA4 actually was not useless in this situation.
It serves as a really great addition to what you can do for detecting the bots. So here I set up
a bit of like a customisation for Evil Jinx Pro where you can set up your own YAML script and to
blacklist specific JA4 signatures, or you can set up what versions of major browsers you allow,
and all of that will be, all the other requests will basically be shown this generic website that
you are redirecting from a different site to actually fool the user that there is no phishing
involved. So here I wanted to tell you to contact me later after the talk and let me know,
probably best to also contact me on the email with the subject ZipCon Breakdown. If you are on the
red team and you want to join the great community of red teamers and want to share information,
it would be great to have you, and everyone is invited, especially from the ZipCon crowd,
because then I can confirm you really exist, so it would be much easier.
So Evil Jinx Pro is actually coming soon, later this year, and how much time do we have still
left? Ten minutes. Okay. So if we have ten minutes, I can actually show you maybe a small live demo,
if I manage to. Okay. So this is the client of Evil Jinx Pro. So you can see right now it is
running on the local machine, and I can actually list all the servers that are being supported by,
that are configured right now, and you will be able to connect to each one of them one by one.
So here I connected to the local server, then I connect to another server that I have on the list,
and this shows you how quickly you can move from one server to another, and you can check the
information and set up based on all of the servers separately. So this gives you like a
quick idea of what to do, and here we will try to make, if we have some more time, I will actually
try to make a demo, because I wanted to show you something interesting. So here I prepared a link
for a Zipcon presentation. Okay. So I'm opening the page. It is also now checking the BotGuard.
You can check that the BotGuard check passed. So that was actually when it gathered the telemetry
in the background, reported it back to Evil Jinx and returned back the response that okay, it is
fine to show the web, the web, the web, the phishing website. Let's just prepare.
Okay. So we got the capture. I have to
so I got the approval request for the MFA that I need to accept. Okay. We are signed in, and okay,
we can see that the authorisation tokens got accepted, so the phishing worked.
Now you can list the session. It is also in the demo mode right now, so you cannot see the password,
it's just filled with asterisks. I will copy the cookies that were captured. Now I will clear the
browsing data to show you how I import the cookies from the intercepted and the captured session.
And now when I open the live.com, which is the real website, this cookie actually provides me access to the
target account. And this is essentially how Evil Jinx worked for the last seven years. But there is one
thing that I wanted to show you as maybe like a funny thing, because when I sign out from live.com,
which is the official Microsoft website, I sign out, okay, you can see that the website is actually
correctly not logging me in. But then when I import the cookies again, tell me what should happen.
We're logged back in again, so Microsoft, you do not only invalidate the session tokens on the client side,
you need to invalidate them also on the server to make it work much more secure. So basically that's the end of the talk.
Thank you. If you have any questions, I will be free later. And I have stickers as well.
Thank you.
